review_title: Pandemic Pushed A  Great Company over the Edge
pros: Great people work here. Worked with people that had been with the company for 40 years or more in some cases. You sacrifice a lot in hospitality whether you are in one of the hotels directly taking care of guests or whether you were in an office or corporate role trying to make your customers happier. But it always felt worth it and you always felt valued.
cons:
Pandemic showed they only cared about their stock price. 
Benefits continue to get less and less valuable.
Perks are shrinking as more hotels are franchised and the higher ups only care about keeping franchisees happy and wall street happy. 
Pay has never been great but as it gets harder to use your associate rate (and you get treated like a nuisance when you check in with it) the below market pay starts to stand out.

review_title: Changing times affecting a traditional company
job_title: Account Executive in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Marriott is a stable and diverse company to work for. It’s giving me many opportunities for an amazing career and meeting amazing colleagues along the way. There are opportunities to make decent money as well as bonuses depending on which business unit you report to.
cons: Marriott uses its power to leverage against customers financially as well as pushes people out who do not fit their conservative ideals. With an entirely new C suite I’ve seen this company change and it’s not for the better. The family feeling the organization has had for decades is gone. The organization from the top down has become based in clicks and managing up versus taking care of the associates to take care of the guests and the guest continue to come back (Marriott’s motto).

pros:
Overall, a good company to work for. Perks included decent pay+tips (On a good night I could make $500 in tips alone), free food, or cheap food at the staff cafeteria, very good healthcare if your working fulltime, and a variety of other smaller things.

Good opportunities to move up, or try new things as well. I worked a variety of roles while there, and gained some amazing experince.
cons:
It's very corporate, and the things that matter most to managers are the bottom line. While not exactly encouraged to over-serve for example, it was an all too common thing as it resulted in higher sales. 

Much of the regular training also reeks of that corporate vibe, and misses the mark. Little is also done to handle problematic employees, which is good in that staff are protected, but bad because racism, homophobia, and other things are all too common.

Lastly, I was regularly called in for OT, either for extended shifts or on my days off. As a young 20-something it was great, but if you have prior commitments, family, or another job, it can be hard. OT can also be tricky to get, as different roles have different thresholds for when they get OT. As a bartender the threshold was after 56 hours, but as a server you got it after 48.

pros: Opportunities to move up, good benefits. CEO and owners have good values and intentions.
cons: Depends on the property but management can really be horrible. Most managers’ goals are to look good to the boss, even if that means throwing their employees under the bus. They tend to do enough to put on their resume then move up after a year or 2. Everyone (and I mean everyone) is severely overworked. Even before the pandemic, we were always understaffed and we were working 10+ hour days. The culture is 10+ hours, 5+ days a week and if you leave after 8 hours, you’re looked at like you don’t care/are blowing it off. Salary pay is so low for the amount of work you’re actually doing. I was very unhappy and don’t plan on returning to hospitality because of my experience.

review_title: Marriott International is a mixed bag of both good and bad
pros: There are some people who genuinely believe in and practice the company culture that Marriott promotes. I had the pleasure to work with some of the most genuine and caring people of my entire career while working with Marriott. If you are lucky and are able to work at one of their decent hotels, you will do very well.
cons: The company is not consistent between what they promote vs what they actually practice. Long time employees might very well find themselves cast aside with no regards to loyalty, and office politics can be extremely toxic depending on which department you are in. If you have ambitions, it is incredibly difficult to rise up in a company that pretends to give everyone a fair shot while mostly playing favorites.

review_title: A Company with many different career paths
job_title: Key Account Manager in Omaha, NE
pros:
* Many different career options available and lots of upward mobility possibilities
* Company puts significant effort into treating employees well and gathering employee feedback regularly
* Loyalty to its associates has resulted in MANY having a great deal of longevity with the company 
* Compensation is generally fair for each position
* Lots of great people as your coworkers and in management. Most everyone at the company is great and someone you would want as a personal friend.
* For a large company, they are generally adaptable and open to change/updates
cons:
* Interview process is challenging, particularly for higher level positions
* Difficult to start off high up within the organization. due to strong hiring from within preference. It is often easier to start lower and work your way up the ladder.
* Often sales goals are inflexible even when there are major changes to accounts (i.e. divestitures)
* Some systems are old, but the company regularly investigates and invests in updates and new systems
* Insane volumes of email to manage in many positions.

pros:
This is one place I know of that if you are in one career and want to get to another, you can do that. I don't know how Marriott has built that culture but they have. That is one of the best things about this company!

I like a high pace workplace and always having things to do. This is what Marriott has given me.
cons:
I've been with Marriott for 13 years and worked at 4 different locations (Phoenix, HQ, and San Francisco).

 1) Marriott HQ is totally out of touch with their associates that are at the hotels. They give tasks that are only busywork thinking it makes work seamless when in reality, it is just more boxes to check off and tasks to complete.

2) They pride themselves in competative pay, but looking around, they pay about 10%-15% less than others for similar positions.

3) Managers are expected to work 50 - 60 work weeks. There goes work life balance if you are looking for it.

4) Arne Sorenson is one of the worst but continues to get praise. Rather than announcing changes to his employees, he makes all of his announcements to the world on MSNBC. All of us found out about layoffs and furloughs the same time the world did... total jerk move.

-Old school leaders and managers, poor emotional intelligence

job_title: Night Auditor in Big Sky Mountain Village, MT
pros: Nice view of the mountains.
cons: It's a very "who you know" workplace in that they pick favorites and discard everyone else's concerns. For the "competitive wages," they also tax all they can and offer healthcare at a high premium - if you need employee housing, expect checks smaller than minimum wage. They say they match 401k on CoolWorks but they haven't since COVID though "they plan to again" like the one movie night they had in the first month which they made F&B cater and left all their trash for them to clean up. Guest clientele are VERY needy, owners come by expecting free everything and are unpleasant to staff, the hotel is oversold more often than it should be. Employees are not given support from absentee management and the environment is toxic what with it being a rumor mill. After being with the hotel since they opened, I cannot say I would ever recommend anyone work here if they didn't have to, which explains why those who aren't fired for making waves end up leaving for better jobs across the street.

job_title: Senior Paralegal/Contract Manager in Frederick, MD
pros: Perhaps the nature of the hospitality industry, most everyone was easy to get along with and friendly.
cons: Initially there were some struggles as we tried to get the pay grades raised for paralegals to be on par with other large corporations in the area. This issue was resolved a number of years ago, and paralegals received a bump in pay in addition to the annual merit increase. One "con" - it is somewhat difficult to get promoted to Managing Paralegal. Promotion is based on "business need" of the particular legal division, funding and number of paralegals in that division. Therefore, you could be in a situation whereby you have seniority and are performing at a level worthy of Managing Paralegal; however, you may be stuck in the Senior Paralegal slot indefinitely, waiting for a Managing Paralegal to leave/retire, or waiting for your division to have the funding and the "business need", which is subjective on the part of HR.

review_title: Great coworkers but an interesting environment
pros: Being a security officer, at the location I worked at, was interesting to say the least. Both the director or security and manager were great people to work with and I enjoyed my time working with them. They were extremely understandable with any questions I had. The schedule wasn’t too bad either. It was generally 4 days on and 3 days off. I would also go as far as saying that my experience working at the Marriott was a huge stepping stone in my career because I had a lot of interactions with guests and having to problem solve certain situations on my own. So for anyone interested in going to law enforcement, this would be an excellent job to get into.
cons: With that in mind,,you really do see the ugly side of people. This job isn’t for everyone and you’ll really be tested by patrons. Generally speaking, the job has its slow days but there will be times, especially in the weekends, where you’ll be in extremely high stress situations. I’ve had my fair share of dealing with highly intoxicated folks who threaten to assault either you or another guest, angry guests who wanted a specific room and acted like a child for not getting what they want, or having to deal with vendors/ djs who will get a hissy fit if you tell them they’re not allowed to load in items using the fire exits. However, dealing with these experiences will further your career down the line and learn excellent verbal judo skills.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: They used to be such a good company to work for, caring about their employees’ well being and their families. Wanting to treat them with respect so they would want to stay and enjoy working there.
cons:
When they acquired the Starwood Hotel brand, the small-town family feel of the company went out the window. This company is now very corporate and cold. And with the impact Covid-19 had on the hotel industry, after the initial swarm of layoffs, I feel as though they want to push out those with tenure to hire cheaper employees to achieve a level of customer service and satisfaction that was barely attainable before the pandemic. 
Therefore, no, I would not recommend anyone to work here. In fact, I stopped recommending it years ago.

Training

Politics, politics, politics - it's exhausting and disheartening

So many systems, layers of hierarchy and corporate offices ... what really happens in the ivory towers is murky and dodgy because it's not about merit, it's about connections 
Some people have titles and responsibilities they do not deserve and when pressed for a decision they will always sacrifice the small people to cover themselves and their friends
